newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian bonds seen rising if Fed sits on hands.
newsitem.headline: Belgian bonds seen rising if Fed sits on hands.

text.p: Belgian linear bonds will get a boost with other markets if the U.S. Federal Reserve, as expected, sits on its hands at today's policy-making meeting.

"The probability of a (rate) hike is 25 percent, but then I'm very bullish: I don't see a (U.S.) rate hike this year," one trader said. "On the other hand I don't expect the U.S. to outperform Germany."
OLOs ended higher ahead of the end of the U.S. Fed meeting, with the yield on the benchmark 2007 OLO easing to 5.74 percent from 5.76 percent on Tuesday evening.
The market continued to ignore a bubbling domestic political scandal, with the 10-year yield over Bunds ending unchanged at seven basis points.

Dealers said that was unlikely to change, even ahead of a vote of confidence on Thursday in the government coalition, which has been rocked by allegations one party (the PS, or French-speaking socialist party) accepted bribes during the award of a defence contract in the late 1980s.
In a separate vote, the regional Walloon Parliament agreed on Wednesday its President and PS figurehead Guy Spitaels could be questioned by police leading the bribes probe.
One trader said volume remained low, but limited buying at the long-end of the curve lent support.
The Belgian franc recovered to above 20.63 to the mark, ending the day at 20.6290/00 from 20.6295/10 at Tuesday's close.
The trader said, however, the spread could move out slightly as convergence trades linked to European economic and monetary union (EMU) were unwound across the continent.
"7-12 (basis points) is fair value," he said.
